text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IPU 22U0709 issued 06-15-2022 updated hyperlink information.
Various editorial changes were made throughout the IRM. Also, cross references and hyperlinks were added, removed, or revised, as appropriate.
IRM 21.7.10, dated 09-11-2020, (effective 10-01-2020), is superseded. The following IPU is incorporated in this publication: IPU 22U0709 issued 06/15/2022.
This IRM is intended for Wage and Investment, Customer Account Services, and Small Business/Self- Employed employees who handle issues related to Business Master File Tax Returns.
Table of Contents

) This section contains information on Business Master File (BMF) account solidation. An unsuccessful attempt to merge (consolidate) an account is Program a no-merge condition. This section also describes the various BMF No-Merge Objectives (NOMRG) transcripts generated by master ﬁle. (

) Purpose: To provide procedures for resolving no-merge condition identiﬁed NOMRG transcripts. • The IRS mission is to provide America’s taxpayers top quality service helping them understand and meet their tax responsibilities and by applying the tax law with integrity and fairness to all. • The IRS will not tolerate discriminatory treatment of taxpayers by its employees in any programs or activities supported by the Service. No taxpayer should be subject to discrimination in educational programs activities based on sex, race, color, national origin, disability, reprisal, religion, or age. • If a taxpayer believes they have been discriminated against on the of sex, race, color, national origin (including limited English disability, reprisal, religion, or age, advise the taxpayer that he/she can forward an e-mail to:*EDI.Civil.Rights.Division@irs.gov, ﬁle a complaint online, a form can be found online at Civil Rights On-Line form, or send a written complaint to: Internal Revenue Service Office of Equity, Diversity and Inclusion, CRU

The IRS will not tolerate discriminatory treatment of taxpayers by its employees in any programs or activities supported by the Service. No taxpayer should be subject to discrimination in educational programs activities based on sex, race, color, national origin, disability, reprisal, religion, or age. The Wage and Investment (W&I) and Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Business Operating Divisions (BODs) are responsible for tax- payer relationships by:
These responsibilities are divided into three subordinate units:
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are Customer Service Representa- tives (CSR) and Tax Examiners (TE) who are assigned no-merge inventory. (
) Policy Owner: The policy owner is the Director, Accounts Management, and Investment Division. (
) Program Owner: The program owner is Process and Program Management (PPM), Accounts Management, Wage and Investment.
Audience: The primary users of this IRM are Customer Service Representa- tives (CSR) and Tax Examiners (TE) who are assigned no-merge inventory.
Program Owner: The program owner is Process and Program (PPM), Accounts Management, Wage and Investment.
Business Tax Returns and Non-Master File Accounts
The Wage and Investment Commissioner has overall responsibility for the policy related to this IRM, which is published on a yearly basis.
Additional information is found in IRM 1.1.13.7.3, Accounts Management, IRM 21.1.1, Accounts Management and Compliance Services Overview.

) Below are additional websites, job aids, or electronic tools that are assist in completing work in Accounts Management: • The Account Management Services (AMS) is a web-based system emphasizes the sharing of key business data and provides a dated and synchronized view of taxpayer data and contact from various IRS systems. • The Correspondence Imaging System (CIS) is for scanning all Management adjustment receipts and correspondence into digital images for case work resolution. • The Employee User Portal (EUP) may be used to view corporate individual electronic tax returns ﬁled via M

• Servicewide Electronic Research Program (SERP) can be utilized to ﬁnd SERP Alerts, IPUs, Correspondex Letters, IRM Supplements other information. • The Electronic Publishing website can be used to research forms, structions, publications, and other Internal Revenue Manuals, procedures and IRS announcements.

• NOMRG FYM - A complete transcript generated when a merge fails because both Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Numbers (TIN) have a ﬁscal year month (FYM). • NOMRG GEN - A complete transcript generated when a merge is attempted, both accounts have an EO section, and the Group Exemption Numbers (GEN) are different (neither EO status is zero).

Below are additional websites, job aids, or electronic tools that are required to assist in completing work in Accounts Management:

The Account Management Services (AMS) is a web-based system emphasizes the sharing of key business data and provides a consoli- dated and synchronized view of taxpayer data and contact from various IRS systems. The Correspondence Imaging System (CIS) is for scanning all Management adjustment receipts and correspondence into digital images for case work resolution. The Employee User Portal (EUP) may be used to view corporate and individual electronic tax returns ﬁled via M

Servicewide Electronic Research Program (SERP) can be utilized to ﬁnd SERP Alerts, IPUs, Correspondex Letters, IRM Supplements and other information. The Electronic Publishing website can be used to research forms, in- structions, publications, and other Internal Revenue Manuals, procedures and IRS announcements.
21.7.10.2 (01-20-2016) What Are No-Merge Transcripts?
NOMRG AF - A complete transcript generated when a merge is attempted, both accounts have an Exempt Organization (EO) and one account has affiliation code of
or
(central organization) the other has affiliation code of
or
(subordinate organization). NOMRG CONS - A transcript generated when the sum of the tion section byte counts, excluding the return byte count, if present, exceeds
bytes. NOMRG DUP - A complete transcript generated when an account merge fails because tax modules for equal periods each contain action Code (TC)

NOMRG FYM - A complete transcript generated when a merge fails because both Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Numbers (TIN) have a different ﬁscal year month (FYM). NOMRG GEN - A complete transcript generated when a merge is attempted, both accounts have an EO section, and the Group Exemption Numbers (GEN) are different (neither EO status is zero).
NOMRG GEN - A complete transcript generated when a merge is attempted, both accounts have an EO section, and the Group Exemption Numbers (GEN) are different (neither EO status is zero).
4 21.7 Business Tax Returns and Non-Master File Accounts
Note: The GEN is a four-digit number that uniquely identiﬁes a central organization and its named subordinates on whose behalf the central organization has applied for a group ruling of exemption.

Since the transcript control will not request documents from Files, cases are distributed to Customer Service Representatives (CSR) inventories. When a paper transcript generates, a control may show on each tax module affected by the account merger. If a CIS transcript generates, the control often shows on only one module of CC TXMOD.
Note: The Associated TINs section of the page isn’t visible while the case is in work distribution (UA). It is visible once the case is assigned to a CSR. (

Exception: If there is an open control on the account, refer Form 4442 to the employee who has the open control.

21.7 Business Tax Returns and Non-Master File Accounts
Complete thorough research to ensure a merger request is appropriate. Review IRM
, Determining if Accounts Can/Should Be Merged. Verify the same taxpayers are involved. Recognize the account module and the entity conditions that prevented a successful merge.
a successful merge. The following transaction codes (TC) are related to entity changes. • TC

- Changes the taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN) of an Account on the Master File (MF) or consolidates two TINs. The input is restricted to the Submission Processing BMF Entity function. The incorrect employer identiﬁcation number (EIN) can be identiﬁed by a series of eights (

) in the Filing Requirement Section of the tran- script. The series of eights also signiﬁes that the account is inactive and may prevent the posting of subsequent transactions. The correct EIN can be identiﬁed by a series of zeros (
) in the Filing Requirement Section. IRM
, Consolidating Accounts, provides detailed in- formation on TC
• TC
- Reopens (Reactivates) an account on MF. The input is re- stricted to the Submission Processing BMF Entity function. This will reverse a TC
IRM
, TC
, provides detailed infor- mation regarding TC
• TC

- Indicates a change to primary name. The authority for making changes to a primary name line is delegated to the Submission Pro- cessing BMF Entity function. Accounts Management employees are authorized to make corrections (e.g., misspellings, input errors, missing or incorrect suffixes). See IRM
, Authority for Making Primary Name Line Changes, for additional information. • TC
- Indicates a change to taxpayer’s address • TC
- Indicates a change to various entity data (e.g., ﬁling require- ments, ﬁscal year month, employment codes, etc.) • TC
- Deletes an account or makes it inactive (changes all ﬁling re- quirement codes to
). The input is restricted to the Submission Processing BMF Entity function. • TC
- Deletes the Entity data that remained on the MF under the old EIN/Social Security Number (SSN) (Generated transaction). • TC
- Changes SSN or name of an account on the valid segment of the Individual Master File (IMF) or the valid portion of the BMF. • TC
- Changes SSN or name of an account which is on the invalid segment of the IMF/Individual Retirement Account File (IRAF) or the invalid portion of the Business Master File (BMF). See Document
, IRS Processing Codes and Information, IRM
Note: See Document 6209, IRS Processing Codes and Information, IRM 3.13.2, BMF Account Numbers, and IRM 2.4, IDRS Terminal Input, for additional in- formation and input requirements.

) An account merger (consolidation) request can be received by phone, corre- spondence, or internal request. Use Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) and Corporate File On Line (CFOL) command codes to research the accounts on master ﬁle to determine whether the accounts can or should be merged (consolidated). If the merge cannot be substantiated by master ﬁle research, request clariﬁcation from the taxpayer.

An account merger (consolidation) request can be received by phone, corre- spondence, or internal request. Use Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) and Corporate File On Line (CFOL) command codes to research the accounts on master ﬁle to determine whether the accounts can or should be merged (consolidated). If the merge cannot be substantiated by master ﬁle research, request clariﬁcation from the taxpayer.
Various items should be considered when researching taxpayer records to stantiate a merge of accounts. Consider the differences in the following:
Name lines
Addresses
Filing requirements (ownership or business structure change)
Entity establishment dates Example: Entities established years apart may indicate different taxpayers. Final returns posted to oldest established taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN) may indicate a
Various items should be considered when researching taxpayer records to stantiate a merge of accounts. Consider the differences in the following:
Entities established years apart may indicate different taxpayers. Final returns posted to oldest established taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN) may indicate a change in ownership.

) Prior to making a merger (consolidation) request, ensure the ﬁling require- ments are compatible. If the ﬁling requirements are not compatible, complete research must be performed to ensure an accurate merger. Taxpayer contact may be necessary. If the taxpayer wants to merge a Form
with a Form

, probe the taxpayer for additional information. A consolidation may be inappropriate. For example, the taxpayer may need to ﬁnalize one account and establish a new business structure type (corporation verses partnership) and request a new employer identiﬁcation number (EIN). Example: One account has a Form 1041 ﬁling requirement and the other a Form 1120 ﬁling requirement. Unless the establishment of one of the ﬁling re- quirements was an IRS error, these accounts should not be merged

One account was established in 2005 and the other in 2014. Final returns have posted to the account established in 2005. This usually indicates a change in ownership and the accounts should not be unless clariﬁcation is received from the taxpayer.
indicates a change in ownership and the accounts should not be unless clariﬁcation is received from the taxpayer. (

) Analyze status of speciﬁc types of tax and tax periods. Example: If the returns are posted under the same tax period and Master File Tax (MFT) code with different liabilities, the entities may be for different taxpayers. (
) When it is determined a merge is necessary, process as follows: a. Attach proper documentation for each entity to Form
, Adjustment Request, (correspondence request) or Form

, Inquiry Referral (phone request). The form must contain the employee number, all research actions, and the reason for the merge. Forward the form to Submission Processing BMF Entity for Transaction Code (TC)

Note: Before forwarding the merge request to Entity, the Accounts Man- agement (AM) manager or lead customer service representative review the case to ensure the accuracy of the merge request. b. The Correspondence Imaging System (CIS) History Notes should accu- rately show the research performed to determine a merger is necessary and the lead/manager concurrence. c. Follow the procedures in the table below.

) A NOMRG-VEST transcript is generated when two accounts attempt to and one or both accounts contain a vestigial (retention) record for the same and tax period. A REVAL-VEST transcript is generated when the ﬁle validity account is returned to the account’s correct Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN) validity. (

) A vestigial record is an account that has been transferred out of Master File (MF) and moved to the Retention Register. The Retention Register is the microﬁlm storage of older, inactive accounts when they are removed from The basic tax module removal criteria include: a. The assessed module balance is zero and the last transaction has posted
or more months. b. The assessed module balance is credit and the last transaction has posted

or more months. c. Credit modules are not subject to speciﬁc retention holds. d. Debit modules past the collection statute expiration date are not to speciﬁc module retention holds. Note: Items c and d will generate a TC
or TC
, respectively, to reduce
If the account consolidation is necessary (the “from” account has a return or payment data necessary to update the “to” account), follow procedures
a. The assessed module balance is zero and the last transaction has been posted
or more months. b. The assessed module balance is credit and the last transaction has been posted
or more months. c. Credit modules are not subject to speciﬁc retention holds. d. Debit modules past the collection statute expiration date are not subject to speciﬁc module retention holds.
Note: Items c and d will generate a TC 388 or TC 608, respectively, to reduce the module balance to zero before removing the module.
Examine the transcripts and returns (if secured) to determine if the account consolidation is necessary. Take the following action:
Request the transcripts for those tax modules on the retention register.
If consolidation is unnecessary or impossible, destroy the transcripts.

If consolidation is necessary, move all available tax modules. The related modules must be available on MF. A tax module that is on the Retention Register cannot be adjusted until it has been restored to MF. In order to restore an account to the master ﬁle (MF) you must obtain a transcript of the account. IRM
, Retention Register Module Research and Reinstatement, provides request guidance.

21.7 Business Tax Returns and Non-Master File Accounts
• The tax module has an overpayment that must be refunded. (

) All available tax modules must be moved to the correct Employer Number (EIN). If a tax module cannot be restored to master ﬁle due to retention period or microﬁlm destruction, do not move the tax module. The research response may indicate the requested tax module is not available (retained) or destroyed. No action is required on these tax modules; however, the Correspondence Imaging System (CIS) History Notes must be update an explanation why the speciﬁc tax module was not moved to the correct EIN. (
) There are two types of retention register: microﬁlm and on-line. IRM
, Retention Register Research, provides instructions for all research command codes utilized through IDRS. and (

) Before requesting retention modules on microﬁlm, use Command Code (CC) BMFOL to check the on-line retention registers to ensure the account module is not available on-line. CC BMFOL deﬁner code B is used to restore recover- able retention register tax modules back to active BMF master ﬁle. A conﬁrmation screen will show a TAX MODULE REQUESTED TO BE REES- TABLISHED message. The weekly cut-off time for BMFOLB requests is
p.m. Wednesday ET. Request input after
p.m. are processed the cycle. IRM
, On-Line Retention Register, provides additional detail. (
) If you determine that microﬁlm research is necessary, make a request using the following methods: • Microﬁlm research can be requested with CC ESTAB deﬁner M. IRM
, Researching Microﬁlm Retention Record, provides addi- tional detail. • A transcript can be obtained by sending a Form

, Request for Research, to the Research Branch. The Research Branch will check microﬁlm records and return a microﬁlm transcript of the account. • CC MFTRA with request type Z is used to request a tax module hard ″ copy transcript. The message A MICROFILM REQUEST HAS BEEN ″ GENERATED will be displayed to show the operator that there is no ″ ″ need to input an ESTAB M request. Ensure the account information not available on the on-line retention register before using CC MFTRA. Note: CC BMFOR can be used to review recently removed tax modules from master ﬁle. The input format for CC BMFOR is the same as for CC BMFOL. These tax modules cannot be re-established to MF through CC BMFOL deﬁner code B. Only BMF modules dropped to retention in
and later are available. See IRM
, Command Code BMFOR Basics, for addi- tional detail. (
) If a tax module cannot be restored with an IDRS command code and a tran- script was secured during research, prepare Form
, Transfer Request, to reactivate the tax module. The transcript is attached to Form
and forwarded to the Accounting Function. Establish an IDRS dummy tax module for the module being restored by Accounting. The account should be restored within
to
weeks.

One Taxpayer Involved (2) Request and review tax returns, if needed. Do the following: 1. Transfer the account involved from the retention register to the Master File. IRM 21.7.10.4.6.4, NOMRG-VEST and REVAL-VEST, and IRM 21.7.10.4.6.4.1, Retention Register Module Research and Reinstatement, provide retention register information, research, and module reinstate- ment. Note: In general, modules brought back from retention on a NMRG-VEST case will merge systemically. 2. Follow NOMRG-DUP procedures if each account has a TC 150 (return posted). If... Then... There is one TC 150 and account can be 1. Research the account to determine whether any merged modules were systemically moved to the correct account. If the account did not merge systemically, send a reactivation (reopen account) request to the Submission Processing BMF Entity function on Form 3465, Adjustment Request. 2. When the reactivation is complete, send a consolida- tion (merger) request to the Submission Processing BMF Entity function using local procedures. 3. If tax returns were pulled for veriﬁcation, reﬁle on the valid EIN with a TC 290 for zero. There are two TC 150 1. Zero out the invalid account and combine tax on the valid account. 2. After the invalid account has been zeroed out, request a TC 020 to deactivate the invalid account. Send the request to the Submission Processing BMF Entity function on Form 3465, Adjustment Request.
